newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenia extends privatisation voucher validity.
newsitem.headline: Slovenia extends privatisation voucher validity.

text.p: Slovenia's government said on Thursday it would prolong the validity of privatisation vouchers, originally set to expire at the end of the month, unitl the end of June 1997 -- the fourth extension in a row.
The government said the extension was needed because the country's mass sell-off scheme had been delayed and as many as 200 companies could not complete their privatisation process until next year.
The delay had partly been caused by revisions in the evaluation of large state companies and their units, it said.

Under Slovenia's privatisation scheme, which started in the beginning of 1994, every Slovene received a voucher whose value varied according to age, ranging from 100,000 tolars ($740) for people under 18 to 400,000 tolars for people over 48.
Until now about 88 percent of Slovenians have spent their vouchers by placing them with Slovenian investment funds or buying shares directly.
Of some 1,500 companies involved in the scheme, about 693 have so far completed the privatisation process.
